name: CT Pulmonary Angiography (Chest CTA for PE)
description: CT angiography timed for pulmonary arterial phase (6–13 sec post-contrast) to evaluate pulmonary arteries for embolism.
contrast_dose: Weight-based; ~100–150 mL iodinated contrast (300 mg I/mL); follow ACR Manual.
renal_safety_notes: Ensure contrast-to-eGFR ratio <1.1 g/(mL/min); if eGFR <30, consider non-contrast alternatives or weigh risks carefully.

name: CT Abdomen & Pelvis with IV Contrast — Portal Venous Phase
description: Single-phase contrast-enhanced CT (portal venous), ideal for broad abdomen/pelvis evaluation.
contrast_timing: Portal venous phase: ∼60–90 sec post-contrast injection.
contrast_dose: Standard ~100–150 mL iodinated contrast; adjust for renal function.
renal_safety_notes: Hydration and dose adjustment recommended; avoid if eGFR <30 unless emergent.

name: Non-Contrast CT Head
description: Rapid non-contrast CT for hemorrhage or infarct evaluation.
renal_safety_notes: Preferred in patients with renal impairment or contrast allergy.

name: Liver Lesion Characterization (LI-RADS Multiphase)
description: Includes non-contrast, arterial, portal venous, and delayed phases as per LI-RADS.
contrast_timing: Arterial (∼35 sec), portal venous (∼70–80 sec), delayed (3–4 min).
contrast_dose: As per abdomen protocol; adjust in renal impairment.
renal_safety_notes: Consider MRI in patients with eGFR <30; use hydration and dose adjustment.

name: Low-Dose CT Chest — Lung Cancer Screening
description: Low-dose CT of lungs targeting <3 mGy radiation dose while maintaining image quality.
renal_safety_notes: Ideal in patients with renal dysfunction due to non-use of contrast.
references: Low-dose CT screening dose benchmarks PMC:contentReference[oaicite:6]{index=6}

name: Trauma CT — Chest, Abdomen & Pelvis with Contrast
description: Contrast CT of torso with trauma-focused reformats; may include delayed images as needed.
contrast_timing: Portal venous phase, possible delayed imaging to assess hemorrhage.
contrast_dose: Standard contrast dose; trauma protocols may include split bolus techniques.
renal_safety_notes: Minimize field-of-view and dose; use alternative imaging if stable and renal risk high.

name: CT Angiography — Carotid Arteries (CTA Neck)
description: CTA through neck using bolus tracking; triggered at specified HU in vessels.
contrast_timing: Start when arterial lumen reaches threshold (~150 HU trigger).
contrast_dose: Adult: ~100 mL iodinated contrast at 4–5 mL/sec; pediatric: 2 mL/kg max.
renal_safety_notes: Arterial studies have high contrast load; assess renal risk and consider MRI/MRA.

name: CT Spine with Contrast (Cervical/Thoracic/Lumbar)
description: Contrast-enhanced CT of spine; includes soft tissue and bone reformats.
contrast_dose: Adult: ~100 mL iodinated contrast; pediatric: 2 mL/kg max.
renal_safety_notes: Use caution in renal impairment; MRI may be preferred.

name: Non-Contrast CT — Orbits and Facial Bones
description: High-resolution bone algorithm non-contrast CT of orbital and facial structures.
renal_safety_notes: Ideal for patients with renal insufficiency or trauma.

name: Non-Contrast CT for Liver Calcification/Stone Detection
description: Non-contrast CT targeting calcified or fat-containing lesions.
renal_safety_notes: Safe modality for renal impairment and repeat imaging.
